messages.text: I will re-read this weekend. I honestly am struggling with the code more than the concept. Ben sent out a collection of notebooks that walk through the pipeline using code. I just walked through one that was super helpful so will continue through those.
The ISLR book has a great section on Ridge/Lasso.  Have you checked that out?
Ridge and LASSO are two ways to penalize for too many or too large coefficients. Now when we check our models with unseen data, it is less likely to blow-up our error term.
If we put a penalty for adding terms or large coefficients, we can get more complexity, but only when it really helps the model.

So think about what we want to achieve with Regularization....we want to use higher complexity models, but we don't want the coefficients to get enormous.
_So how can we achieve this?_

Hey guys, I fell behind a little bit yesterday on the individual/pair.  I don’t think I had a lot of trouble conceptually until ridge/lasso, but wasn’t moving very fast on the assignments. Do either of you have any suggestions on further resources? I will certainly focus my weekend on reviewing the programming task.
Using `$ ipython --pylab` starts up the ipython terminal with improved event handling _(like not freezing up the command line while a plot is open, etc.)_.

Hey guys, I recall you teaching me a line I should put in the terminal (or maybe in ipython) that I should use before starting to plot with matplotlib. It seemed to just be a standard you both use to prevent possible issues…any chance you remember what I am talking about?
